categories.name: Acceptance Criteria
checkList: Clear acceptance criteria are defined and agreed upon.
Acceptance criteria are reviewed and signed off by the product owner.

categories.name: Requirements
checkList: All functional and non-functional requirements are captured.
The scope of the Epic is clearly defined and documented.

categories.name: Design Review
checkList: Initial wireframes or design mockups are reviewed by the design team.
Feedback from stakeholders has been incorporated into the design.

categories.name: Stakeholder Approval
checkList: The Epic is reviewed and approved by key stakeholders.
Sign-off has been documented and logged in the system.

categories.name: Dependencies
checkList: Dependencies with other Epics or stories are identified.
A plan is created to manage these dependencies.

categories.name: Technical Review
checkList: Technical feasibility has been evaluated by the development team.
Potential risks and challenges are documented and mitigation strategies outlined.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: All relevant documentation (e.g., technical specs, user stories) is completed.
Documentation is stored in an accessible repository for future reference.

categories.name: Readiness for Implementation
checkList: The Epic is marked as ‘Ready for Development’ by the project manager.
All team members are briefed on the Epic's objectives and scope.

categories.name: Requirement Analysis
checkList: Feature request is documented with a clear description and purpose.
All relevant requirements, including functional and non-functional, are captured.

categories.name: Feasibility Assessment
checkList: The development team has conducted a technical feasibility assessment.
Risks and constraints associated with the feature are identified and noted.

categories.name: Stakeholder Input
checkList: Feedback from stakeholders has been gathered and reviewed.
The feature has been prioritized based on business value and urgency.

categories.name: Design Validation
checkList: Initial design or wireframes are created and shared with the design team.
Design review feedback is incorporated, ensuring alignment with UX/UI standards.

categories.name: Acceptance Criteria
checkList: Clear and specific acceptance criteria are defined and agreed upon by stakeholders.
Acceptance criteria are documented in the feature request ticket.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: Supporting documentation (e.g., user stories, technical specs) is completed.
Documentation is linked or stored in an accessible location.

categories.name: Dependency Check
checkList: Dependencies with other features, components, or external systems are identified.
A plan is in place to address dependencies and potential conflicts.

categories.name: Approval and Sign-Off
checkList: Feature request has been reviewed and approved by the product owner or relevant stakeholders.
Approval is logged in the system for traceability.

categories.name: Ready for Development
checkList: All preparatory work is completed and marked as ready for development.
Development team has been briefed on the feature request details.

categories.name: Reproduction Steps
checkList: Clear and detailed steps to reproduce the defect are documented.
Screenshots, logs, or any relevant evidence are attached to illustrate the issue.

categories.name: Root Cause Analysis
checkList: The root cause of the defect has been identified by the development team.
Notes on how the issue occurred and potential implications are documented.

categories.name: Impact Assessment
checkList: The impact on the application, users, or system performance is evaluated.
Severity and priority levels are assigned based on the impact analysis.

categories.name: Fix Implementation
checkList: Code changes have been implemented to resolve the defect.
The code has been reviewed and approved by a peer or lead developer.

categories.name: Testing
checkList: The defect fix has been tested in a development or staging environment.
Automated or manual test cases have been executed to verify the fix.

categories.name: Regression Testing
checkList: Regression testing has been conducted to ensure no new issues were introduced.
All related components or areas that could be affected have been tested.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: Relevant documentation, such as release notes or change logs, is updated.
Any changes to technical or user documentation are completed and shared.

categories.name: Approval
checkList: The fix has been approved by the QA team or relevant stakeholders.
Sign-off from the product owner or a responsible party is documented.

categories.name: Deployment Readiness
checkList: The defect fix is included in a build marked ready for deployment.
The deployment process has been reviewed and planned with the operations team.

categories.name: Requirement Analysis
checkList: The specific improvement and scope of the enhancement are clearly defined.
Any existing limitations or issues that the enhancement addresses are documented.

categories.name: Feasibility Review
checkList: The development team has reviewed the technical feasibility of the enhancement.
Potential risks or challenges have been noted, and mitigation strategies are proposed.

categories.name: Stakeholder Feedback
checkList: Feedback from users or stakeholders regarding the current feature has been collected.
The proposed enhancement has been reviewed and aligned with stakeholder needs.

categories.name: Design Update
checkList: Design updates (wireframes, mockups, etc.) have been created and shared.
Feedback from the design team has been incorporated into the updated design.

categories.name: Acceptance Criteria
checkList: Clear and updated acceptance criteria are defined for the enhancement.
Acceptance criteria are approved by relevant stakeholders.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: Existing documentation has been reviewed and updated to reflect the enhancement.
New documentation (if needed) has been created and linked to the enhancement ticket.

categories.name: Testing Plan
checkList: A comprehensive testing plan is prepared to cover both the new enhancement and any affected areas.
Test cases have been written and are ready for execution.

categories.name: Dependency Check
checkList: Any dependencies on other features, modules, or teams have been identified.
A plan to handle dependencies or avoid conflicts has been documented.

categories.name: Approval
checkList: The enhancement proposal has been reviewed and approved by the product owner.
Sign-off has been documented for traceability.

categories.name: Ready for Development
checkList: All preparatory work, including analysis and documentation, is completed.
The development team is briefed and ready to begin work on the enhancement.

categories.name: Incident Documentation
checkList: A detailed description of the incident is documented, including error messages, screenshots, or logs.
Relevant metadata (e.g., incident timestamp, affected environment, severity level) is included.

categories.name: Impact Assessment
checkList: The impact on the customer or business is evaluated and documented.
The urgency and priority of the incident are clearly defined.

categories.name: Reproduction Steps
checkList: Clear steps to reproduce the incident are provided.
Any attempts to reproduce the incident have been documented.

categories.name: Initial Troubleshooting
checkList: Basic troubleshooting has been performed and logged.
Relevant findings or logs from initial analysis are attached.

categories.name: Communication
checkList: Initial acknowledgment of the incident has been sent to the customer or stakeholder.
Regular updates have been scheduled or provided to keep stakeholders informed.

categories.name: Resolution Strategy
checkList: A plan for resolving the incident has been created and documented.
Potential workarounds or temporary solutions have been proposed if applicable.

categories.name: Fix Implementation
checkList: The issue has been resolved and verified in a controlled environment.
Code changes, if necessary, have been peer-reviewed and approved.

categories.name: Testing
checkList: The fix has been tested to confirm the issue is resolved and does not impact other areas.
Regression testing has been performed to ensure system stability.

categories.name: Customer Confirmation
checkList: The resolution has been communicated to the customer or stakeholder.
Feedback from the customer confirming the fix has been received and documented.

categories.name: Documentation Update
checkList: Internal documentation, such as incident logs or knowledge base articles, has been updated.
Lessons learned from the incident have been documented for future reference.

categories.name: Closure
checkList: The incident is marked as resolved and closed after final verification.
All related parties have been informed of the incident closure.

categories.name: Description and Context
checkList: A clear and concise description of the user story is provided.
The 'who', 'what', and 'why' are outlined to provide context (e.g., 'As a [user], I want [feature], so that [benefit]').

categories.name: Acceptance Criteria
checkList: Well-defined acceptance criteria are listed to ensure clear expectations.
Criteria are reviewed and approved by the product owner or relevant stakeholders.

categories.name: Priority and Estimation
checkList: The user story has been assigned a priority level.
Effort estimation (story points or time-based) is completed and agreed upon by the team.

categories.name: Task Breakdown
checkList: The user story is broken down into subtasks for easier tracking and assignment.
Each subtask has a clear owner and an estimated completion time.

categories.name: Dependencies and Blockers
checkList: Dependencies on other user stories, tasks, or external factors are identified.
Blockers are documented, and a plan for addressing them is noted.

categories.name: Design and Mockups
checkList: Any required design or UI mockups are created and attached to the user story.
The design has been reviewed and approved by the design team, if applicable.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: Any relevant documentation, such as user guides or technical notes, is linked or attached.
The documentation is stored in an accessible location for team reference.

categories.name: Stakeholder Review
checkList: The user story has been reviewed by stakeholders to ensure alignment with goals.
Feedback from stakeholders has been incorporated as needed.

categories.name: Readiness for Development
checkList: The user story is marked as 'Ready for Development' with all necessary information completed.
Team members are briefed on the story’s details and objectives.

categories.name: Testing Plan
checkList: A testing plan or criteria for validating the completion of the user story is defined.
QA has been briefed on the expected outcomes and any specific testing requirements.

categories.name: Objective and Description
checkList: A clear objective for the spike is documented, explaining what needs to be researched or analyzed.
A detailed description is included, outlining the problem or question the spike aims to address.

categories.name: Scope Definition
checkList: The scope of the spike is defined to avoid open-ended research.
Clear deliverables or outcomes are specified (e.g., findings, prototypes, reports).

categories.name: Timebox
checkList: The spike is timeboxed with a set duration (e.g., one sprint or a specific number of hours).
The team agrees on the time limit to maintain focus and avoid scope creep.

categories.name: Research Plan
checkList: A plan or approach for conducting the spike is outlined (e.g., data collection methods, tools to be used).
Initial resources and references are identified to guide the investigation.

categories.name: Dependencies and Resources
checkList: Any dependencies or required resources (e.g., access to specific environments, data, or stakeholders) are identified.
A plan to acquire or coordinate these resources is documented.

categories.name: Collaboration and Stakeholders
checkList: Stakeholders or team members involved in the spike are listed.
Roles and responsibilities for collaboration are outlined.

categories.name: Documentation of Findings
checkList: A document or report summarizing the findings of the spike is created.
Key insights, potential solutions, and recommendations are included in the findings.

categories.name: Review and Approval
checkList: The findings of the spike are reviewed by the team or relevant stakeholders.
Feedback from the review is incorporated as necessary.

categories.name: Outcome Decision
checkList: A decision based on the findings of the spike is made (e.g., go/no-go for a feature, direction to proceed).
The decision and next steps are documented and communicated to the team.

categories.name: Closure
checkList: The spike is marked as completed and closed after all findings are documented and shared.
Any related tasks or follow-up stories are created based on the outcomes of the spike.

categories.name: Preparation
checkList: Identify documentation goals
Gather necessary resources
Set documentation standards
Outline key topics

categories.name: Writing and Review
checkList: Draft initial documentation
Conduct peer review
Revise based on feedback
Publish final version

categories.name: Clear Objective
checkList: The subtask has a clear objective that aligns with the parent task or user story.
A concise description explaining the purpose and scope of the subtask is provided.

categories.name: Assignment and Ownership
checkList: The subtask is assigned to a specific team member for accountability.
The assignee understands their role and the expectations for completing the subtask.

categories.name: Dependencies
checkList: Any dependencies related to other subtasks or external tasks are identified.
A plan is documented to address dependencies or potential blockers.

categories.name: Acceptance Criteria
checkList: Acceptance criteria are defined to confirm the completion of the subtask.
The criteria are clear, actionable, and reviewed by the team.

categories.name: Effort Estimation
checkList: The subtask has an estimated time or effort required for completion.
The estimate has been agreed upon and reviewed by the team.

categories.name: Documentation
checkList: Relevant documentation, links, or references are attached if needed.
Any notes or updates related to the subtask are included for transparency.

categories.name: Progress Updates
checkList: Regular progress updates are added to keep the team informed.
Any issues or challenges encountered are logged and addressed promptly.

categories.name: Review and Completion
checkList: The completed subtask is reviewed to ensure it meets the acceptance criteria.
Feedback from the review is applied if changes are needed.

categories.name: Closure
checkList: The subtask is marked as complete after verification by the assigned reviewer.
The parent task or user story is updated to reflect the progress or completion of the subtask.

categories.name: Objective and Scope
checkList: A clear objective for the quality story is documented, specifying the feature or functionality to be tested.
The scope of the quality story is defined, including what will be covered in testing and any specific areas of focus.

categories.name: Test Plan Creation
checkList: A comprehensive test plan outlining the testing strategy and approach is created.
The test plan includes types of tests to be executed (e.g., functional, regression, performance).

categories.name: Test Case Development
checkList: Test cases are written for all new features or changes to be verified.
Each test case includes clear steps, expected results, and any prerequisites.

categories.name: Verification and Validation
checkList: Testing is conducted to verify that the feature meets acceptance criteria.
Any issues or defects identified during testing are documented and communicated to the development team.

categories.name: Documentation of Testing Results
checkList: Test results are documented, including pass/fail status for each test case.
Any discrepancies or additional findings are noted for review.

categories.name: Feature Documentation Review
checkList: Feature documentation is created or updated to reflect the testing outcomes and any changes made.
Documentation is reviewed for accuracy and completeness.

categories.name: Stakeholder Communication
checkList: Results and findings from the quality story are communicated to relevant stakeholders.
Any necessary follow-up actions or decisions are documented and tracked.

categories.name: Closure and Retrospective
checkList: The quality story is marked as complete once all tests have been executed and documentation is finalized.
Lessons learned and feedback from the testing process are gathered for future improvement.

categories.name: Integration into Agile Backlog
checkList: The quality story is included in the agile backlog, ensuring visibility and prioritization.
Quality engineers are assigned to the story to ensure accountability.
